page.lettertext:
fol.21r
May it please yo
r
good L. w
t
her
Hig
nes
letter unto me of the 19 of De
c
and one from the
LL.
of the Councel of the same date, I have
receaved yo
r
L. of
e 21 w
ch
came all unto my handes
e 7 of
this present. If I knewe any way more dutifull then
other, to give her Ma
tie
assurance of my gratitude of minde,
and of my speciall inclination to deserve so good a token of her
Princely favo
r
, I would willingly declare it both by wordes
and effectes. But because this grace doth come unto
me, by yo
r
L. good report, and you knowe w
t
what ende-
vo
rs
I may give her Ma
tie
best content, I am to pray you
most humbly, to undertake in my behalf (and I hope to
perfourme it to yo
r
full satisfaction) that I will never lette
slippe, w
at
soever I am able, any part of any service,
at
may be gratefull to her Hig
nes
. It was a grievous
corrosive unto me, that was written from yo
r
L. about the
weakenesse of
e companies,
at were sent from this place
for
e siege of
Rouen.
Whiche also moveth me the more,
for
at I feare at other times, and in other like causes, some
suche offences may be taken, as (submittinge it further to
yo
r
L. consideration) I am not any way to answear. For
I had never yet any charge, sins my first comming hither,
nether from
e LL. of
e Councel, nor yet from yo
r
L.
by letter or otherwise, to deale in any matter appartening
to the Musters. I had never no copie sent unto me, as
there was to other Officers, of any orders or instructions,
that were at any time sent hither as there were at sundrie
times, for divers speciall reformations. For w
ch
I could
not but presume, that it was not any way intended that I
should meddle w
t
those affaires. And wheras by
e last
newe Establishement, for the distribution of her Ma
ties
paies
(wherof in like sort I have had no copie sent unto me) it
is ordened that 3 bookes should be kept by
e Commissaries
to be sent at the ende of every 6 monethes, to
M
r
Wilkes
to the T
re
r and to me, and
at to me to be presented to
the
Councel of state
, it was never yet perfourmed by any
fol.21v
towardes me. Yet though I had no order, nor letter [about it, I]
woulde not have omitted to calle uppon them for it, [but that]
the Councel of State hath alwaies made me an[swear, that]
they cannot accept of any Musters, but suche as [are passed]
aswell by their owne, as by her Ma
ties
Commissa[ries, and]
in one kinde of order w
t
owt
e allowance of the d[ead paies]
and of sundrie other pointes, w
ch
are otherwise s[et down]
in her Ma
ties
orders, then they will be persuaded
to practise
or approve. M
r
Wilkes can report unto yo
r
[L. their]
precise proceeding in
at respect, w
ch
is also spec[ified by]
e Apostilles of the states to his last Propos[itions]
It may happely be,
at yo
r
L. doth conceave, that being [here in]
place, I might have knowen by relation, or by some o[ther ready]
meanes,
e strength of every company. But I doe [assure yo
r
]
L. it is not posible for me, not having
e opportun[ity to]
see an Englishe company, but when they come to se[rvice, and]
when the Councel is present, w
ch
is never but in [sommer]
and then very seeldome: and yet of those
at are im
ployed in
e feelde, there is hardly the third of her Ma
ties
for[ces.]
My best intelligence for the state of the companies [might come]
from
e Commissaries of
e Musters, but their usual r[esidence]
is so farre from
e Hage, at
e
Brille
sette a part I
can
hardly send to the neerest unto me, and be sure of his a[nswear]
under eighte or nine daies. Moreover because I [greatly]
doubted, lest
e foresaide companies woulde be founde v[ery weak,]
for
at I knewe they had bin spent, partly by service [this]
sommer partly by sicknes, and no supplies sent over, [besides]
the nombers
at would flie from their Captaines, befo[re they]
came to embarking, if you please to calle it to minde [I did]
signifie in my letter of
e 20 of No
v
at for
e ren[forcement]
of
e troupes, some supplie woulde be needfull [to be sent]
unto
Diepe.
There are at this present, as I [writte]
yo
r
L. in my last, twenty Enseignes of these con[treys that]
attend but a winde to be shipped for
France,
of w[hich there]
are 5 at
e lest of 200 in a bande, and
e rest of [150 and]
130 so as being complete they might reche to
e n[umber of]
fol.22r
3000 at the lest, and yet by reason of the foresaide accidents this
last sommer, it is generally supposed,
at they will scantly amount
to 2000 in all, w
ch
will scarcely prove so good a reckeninge as of
e
Englishe troupes: considering that
e Dutche companies have
no allowance of dead paies. I take litle pleasure, to putte
yo
r
L. to this trouble, to hearken to the reasons of my privat
defence: but I beseeche you to impute it to mine earnest desire,
not to seeme any other then I will be alwaies, and I trust I
have bin hitherto, w
ch
is as carefull to acquite, what my duty
shall require, as can be expected at my handes. Yo
r
L. I am
sure shall never have good cause to be otherwise persuaded: as
nowe I hope in this pointe of
e companies defectes, yow are
better informed of my dealing, and will vouchesafe in that respect,
to remove every sparkle of her Ma
ties
displeasure. But if I
shall at any time receave any manner of charge in regard of
e
Musters wherby it may not be conceaved, that I meddle by
intrusion in
e offices of others ether heere or at home, there
shall nothing be wanting to the diligent perfourmance of
at her
Hig
nes
shall commaund. for hitherto in truth I have alwaies
understoode, that M
r
Wilkes had a special Commission, to
examine the proceedinges of
e Englishe Commissaries, and to
looke into all matters belonging to the
y
musters: for w
ch
cause,
and for that I was never required, as likewise
at
e Gouver-
no
rs
of Garrisons and others (who ought to have
e care to
keepe their companies complete and may easely doe it, having
them alwaies in their sight) might not thinke me over busie in
e affaires of their charge, I alwaies thought I might be excused
if I should not deale any further, then I was specially autorised.
As touching those Musters, w
ch
my LL of the Councell are
desirous, should be passed by
e Officers of
e states, I have
written an answear in a letter a part, w
ch
yo
r
L. will be plea
sed to deliver unto them. For an answear to
e letter w
ch
was written from
Mons
r
de Bilandt
one of
e
Emperors
Am-
bassadors at Brussels, wherof I made mention in my last to
yo
r
L. it is nowe resolved,
at he shall have licence to come
hither. The Deputies of
e
General states
of whose
fol.22v
recesse I have written in my former letters, are not yet [returned: but]
e Councel of state, to whome
e foresaide Ambassado
r
[addressed]
his letter aswell as to the states, have sent a Passeport
unto him
They have endevoured hitherto, by suche devises and ex[cuses, as]
I have alwaies imparted by my letters to yo
r
L. to stop[pe the]
comminge hither of
e Ambassadors. Nowe not[withstanding]
that accesse is required but for one of their nomber [which is]
also reputed an honest favourer of their cause, it is [thought by]
this Councel, at
e admission of him, will serve them [for a]
colour, to shake of the rest, and yet to satisfie the [Emperor]
and
e Princes of
Germany
as touching their des[ire to]
come to a Pacification. For seeing there is no [meeting]
of
e General states, to whome it properly belong[eth, to give]
audience, and answear, in affaires of
at nature, it is [considered]
that this Councel may very well refuse it, as having [no authority]
to answear an Ambassado
r
, and yet by worde of mou[th and by]
way of co
m
unication (for happely by writinge they [might be]
more bounde and entangled, then they woulde be) th[ey may]
both make an excuse in
e behalf of
e states, for [that the]
Ambassado
rs
were not hitherto admitted, by reason of [their]
recesse, and notifie w
t
all w
at
manner of peace, they doe [mind]
to embrace: wherin they thinke
at
e contreis turne [may be]
served, both for answearinge
e Empero
r
and for cleanly
casting
of the Ambassadors Proposition, and likewise for [drawing]
somwhat in conference of
e Ennemies drift in the [moving]
of this Treaty: and all w
t
out prejudice to themselves, o[r to the]
contrey. For besides
at they are purposed to answear [to all]
thinges w
t
a speciall reserve, it is considered that the [actions of]
the Councel in causes surpassing the autoritie of thei[r college]
are not any way obligatorie to the states in generall [it is]
conditioned in
e foresaid Passeport
at Mons
r
de Bi[landt must]
come forward w
t
out delay and not to bring w
t
him [above 12]
persons. There is also order taken at comming to [Lillo he]
shall be receaved by an officer of
e Admiraltie and [by him]
conducted by water to the Hage.
Hage
January
10
